Module schiffeversenken
Package de.uniluebeck.itm.schiffeversenken.engine

Class Controller<Model>

java.lang.Object
de.uniluebeck.itm.schiffeversenken.engine.Controller<Model>
Direct Known Subclasses:
ComponentController, GameController
public abstract class Controller<Model> extends Object
Instantiate this class in order to implement your user interaction logic.
Author:
leondietrich

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors
    Constructor
    Description
    Controller(Model m)
    This constructor doesn't do anything fancy beside initializing the model.

  • Constructor Details

    • Controller

      public Controller(Model m)
      This constructor doesn't do anything fancy beside initializing the model.
      Parameters:
      m - The model to use.

  • Method Details

    • getModelInstance

      public final Model getModelInstance()
      Use this method in order to access the underlying model.
      Returns:
      the model instance.

    • clickedAt

      public abstract void clickedAt(Vec2 position)
      Use this method to check where the user clicked at your scene.
      Parameters:
      position - The mouse cursor position relative to your scene.

    • keyPressed

      public abstract void keyPressed(int key, boolean shift, boolean alt, boolean ctrl, boolean down, boolean up, boolean left, boolean right)
      Use this method in order to receive newly pressed keys
      Parameters:
      key - The pressed key
      shift - Was the shift modifier pressed?
      alt - Was the ALT modifier pressed?
      ctrl - Was the CTRL modifier pressed?
      down - Was the down arrow key pressed?
      up - Was the up arrow key pressed?
      left - Was the left arrow key pressed?
      right - Was the right arrow key pressed?

    • performFrequentUpdates

      public abstract void performFrequentUpdates()
      This method gets called just before the view renders the scene. Use it to perform last minute updates but keep in mind that you're computing on the graphics thread. This means that your're better of delegating heavy workloads to the dispatchWork method.

    • dispatchWork

      public void dispatchWork(Runnable r)
      Use this method in order to enqueue work to be processed later on. Don't use it for endless loops as they need to finish in finite time.
      Parameters:
      r - The runnable that should be enqueued.

    • startWorkStack

      public void startWorkStack()
      This method starts the processing of the dispatched work queue. It is safe to call it in fast cycles as it wont create any threads as long as there are enough.

    • hasWork

      public final boolean hasWork()
      Use this method in order to check if the controller has an active (full) work queue. Keep in mind that this method will also return true if there is no work within the queue but threads are still processing older tasks.
      Returns:
      True if there is still unprocessed work to do.

    • stop

      public void stop() throws InterruptedException
      This method gets called when the scene gets detached. Override it in order to stop your interfacing logic. But don't forget to call your super():
      Throws:
      InterruptedException

    • prepare

      public abstract void prepare()
      Use this method in order to prepare the controller for being rendered by a view.
